Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 50385-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
September 2017 
 
 
 
Strengthening Institutions for Localizing Agenda 
2030 for Sustainable Development 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Public Communications 
Policy 2011. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
DeLoG  –  Development Partners Network on Decentralisation and 
    Local Governance 
DMCs  –  developing member countries 
GovTG  –  Governance Thematic Group 
PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
SDG  –  Sustainable Development Goal 
TA  –  technical assistance 
UN  –  United Nations 
UNDP  –  United Nations Development Programme 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  B. Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development   
Director General  A. Leung, Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
(SDCC) 
Technical Advisor    G. Bhatta, Technical Advisor (Governance), SDCC 
 
Team leader  C. Buentjen, Principal Public Management Specialist, SDCC 
Team members  S. Azfar, Urban Development Specialist, Central and West Asia 
Department 
J. Jacinto-Aquino, Operations Analyst, SDCC 
H. Rahemtulla, Senior Public Management Specialist, SDCC 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

CONTENTS 
Page 
KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE 
I.  INTRODUCTION  1 
II.  ISSUES  1 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  2 
A.  Impact and Outcome  2 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  2 
C.  Cost and Financing  4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  4 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  5 
 
APPENDIXES  
1.  Design and Monitoring Framework  6 
2.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan  8 
3.  List of Linked Documents  9

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  proposed  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  improve  the 
institutional capacity of selected Asian Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries 
(DMCs) to localize the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).1 In response to DMC demand, 
the proposed TA will add value to the programs and operations of regional departments by 
supporting (i) the strengthening of awareness, knowledge, and skills for effective localization of 
the SDGs in selected DMCs; (ii) testing of innovative institutional capacity interventions for 
localizing SDGs in selected DMCs; and (iii) enhancing dialogue, including among developing 
countries, on good practices in SDG localization.2 
 
2.  The proposed TA is included in the 2017 work program of the Governance Thematic 
Group  (GovTG).3 It  builds  on  previous  knowledge  activities  of  the  GovTG,  such  as  the 
conferences conducted jointly with the Development Partners Network on Decentralisation and 
Local  Governance  (DeLoG)  in  August  2015  and  September  2016,4 and  the  international 
conference on the Role of Managing for Development Results in Achieving the SDGs 2030 (June 
2017).5 The proposed TA also takes into account the lessons from a series of learning programs 
on Multi-Stakeholder Engagement for Reform in different settings.6 The TA is aligned with recent 
ADB strategy and policy papers on public sector management, institutional performance, and 
capacity development, and factors in lessons from past and ongoing decentralization and local 
governance operations in countries such as Cambodia, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
Indonesia, Nepal, and the Philippines.7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In September 2015, the United Nations (UN) General Assembly adopted Agenda 2030 
(Transforming Our World: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development), which includes 17 
SDGs and 169 targets, as a new reference for global development efforts. ADB supports its DMCs 
in achieving the SDGs through a customized approach with respect to sustainable development 
investments and enhanced financing needs, and by incorporating sustainability into its corporate 
results framework and reporting processes and enhanced financing needs.8  
 
                                                
1  Localization is defined as “the process of taking into account subnational contexts in the achievement of the 2030 
Agenda, from the setting of goals and targets to determining the means of implementation and using indicators to 
measure and monitor progress”. Global Task-Force of Local and Regional Governments. 2016. Roadmap for 
Localising  the  SDGs:  Implementing  and  Monitoring  at  Subnational  Level. 
https://www.uclg.org/sites/default/files/roadmap_for_localizing_the_sdgs_0.pdf. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 September 2017. 
3   The TA is included under the title Strengthening Institutions for Global Agendas.  
4  ADB. 2015. Support for Decentralization Reforms and Local Governance Systems in the Asia-Pacific: Better 
Performance, Higher Impact. Manila. 25–27 August. https://www.eiseverywhere.com/ehome/adb-decentralization-
event/GovTGevent-corruption-home/; ADB. 2016. Localizing Global Agendas. Manila. 27–29 September. http://k-
learn.adb.org/learning-events/localizing-global-agendas. 
5   ADB. 2017. The Role of Managing for Development Results in Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals 2030. 
Manila. 15–16 June. https://www.adb.org/news/events/role-mfdr-achieving-sdgs-2030. 
6   ADB. 2014, 2015, 2016. Mobilizing Multi-Stakeholder Action for Reform. Manila. http://k-learn.adb.org/learning-
events/2016-mobilizing-multi-stakeholder-action-reform.  
7  ADB. 2016. Better Performing Institutions in ADB Developing Member Countries: Positioning ADB’s Approach to 
Public Sector Management and Institutional Performance. Manila; ADB. 2015. Review of the Asian Development 
Bank’s Approach to Capacity Development. Manila. 
8  ADB. ADB’s Focus on Sustainable Development Goals. https://www.adb.org/site/sdg/main (accessed on 5 July 
2017).

2 
4.  Unlike the Millennium Development Goals, which were highly centralized, the SDGs 
capture  environmental,  economic,  political,  and  social  dimensions  of  development  more 
holistically. While the text of the SDGs does not contain an explicit call for localizing the SDGs, 
local governments are recognized directly or indirectly in many of the goals, notably in Goal 11 
(Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable) and Goal 16 
(Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice 
for all, and build effective, accountable, and inclusive institutions at all levels). 
 
5.  Subnational governments have a critical role in implementing and achieving the SDGs, 
including those where localization is not explicitly mentioned, because (i) the experience of 
developed countries suggests that as economic and population growth and urbanization increase 
a greater share of public investments and spending will occur at the local level; (ii) addressing 
global resource challenges and constraints—such as pollution, biodiversity loss, and climate 
change—will  require  close  involvement  of  subnational  governments;  and  (iii)  subnational 
governments are closer to citizens and better positioned to provide opportunities for the poor and 
marginalized to be heard. The proposed TA will support implementation of the roadmap for 
localizing the SDGs developed by the Global Taskforce of Local and Regional Governments, the 
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and UN Habitat to support cities and regions 
to deliver the 2030 agenda; roadmap development included an intensive consultation process 
(footnote 1).9  
 
6.  Many  DMCs  lack  the  institutional  capacity  to  localize  the  SDGs,  and  institutional 
strengthening is needed with respect to: (i) multilevel governance systems defined by national 
governments (i.e., related to functional assignments, intergovernmental fiscal relations, and 
national–subnational development plan integration); (ii) subnational governmental processes, to 
ensure that regulations, planning and budgeting processes; service delivery mechanisms; and 
infrastructure investments are responsive to SDG goals; and (iii) transparent and participatory 
multi-stakeholder engagement processes involving local governments and parliaments, citizens, 
and the private sector to ensure accountability on SDG target achievement, drawing on adequate 
national and subnational monitoring systems. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: performance of institutions in DMCs for 
localizing Agenda 2030 commitments for sustainable development improved. The TA will have 
the following outcome: institutional capacity of selected DMCs to localize the SDGs improved.10  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities  
8.  The proposed TA will support three key outputs, which are designed to respond flexibly to 
various potential DMC institutional strengthening needs for localizing the SDGs (para. 6). The 
ultimate support areas under the TA will be determined through consultations with regional 
                                                
9  The consultations generated the following key messages: (i) local and regional governments are essential for 
promoting  inclusive  sustainable  development  within  their  territories  and  are  necessary  partners  in  SDG 
implementation; (ii) effective local governance can ensure that a diversity of local stakeholders are included, which 
encourages broad-based ownership, commitment, and accountability; (iii) an integrated multilevel and multi-
stakeholder approach is needed to promote transformative local agendas; and (iv) a strong commitment is required 
at the national level to provide adequate legal frameworks and institutional and financial capacity. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
departments and DMCs. The TA can support the localizing of any of the SDGs, but the highest 
demand is expected to be for the service delivery- and infrastructure-related SDGs, as well as for 
goals related to sustainable cities, the environment, and climate action.  
 
9.  Output  1:  Awareness,  knowledge,  and  skills  for  effective  localization  of  the 
Sustainable Development Goals in selected developing member countries strengthened. 
Under output 1, at least three customized regional or country-specific learning programs will be 
developed and conducted, focusing on the awareness, knowledge, and skills needed to localize 
the SDGs. At least 150 local stakeholders, preferably involved in ADB projects, will participate in 
the programs by December 2019. An existing program on Multi-Stakeholder Engagement for 
Reform developed by ADB and tested through ADB staff training since 2007 will be customized 
to better respond to SDG implementation challenges. The program teaches critical skills—such 
as understanding stakeholders and their underlying interests and power relations— in support of 
collective action in complex multi-stakeholder settings. The TA will respond to a request by the 
Pacific Department to implement a customized version of the Multi-Stakeholder Engagement for 
Reform learning program for participants involved in the Improving Quality of Basic Education 
Project in the Republic of the Marshall Islands and the Federated States of Micronesia. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Innovative  institutional  capacity  interventions  for  localizing  the 
Sustainable Development Goals in selected developing member countries tested. Under 
output 2, at least two subprojects that respond to any of the various institutional strengthening 
needs (para. 6) will be identified in close cooperation with regional departments and DMCs, and 
be  implemented  by  March  2020.  Subprojects  that  present  challenges  in  the  form  of  high 
institutional  complexity,  innovation  or  learning  potential  will  be  prioritized,  with  findings 
disseminated to DMC decision makers and ADB programs and operations. One subproject will 
support the Institute for SDGs at Tsinghua University in cooperation with the UNDP office in the 
PRC to support testing of an innovative approach to integrating the SDGs into local 5-year plans 
in up to two cities in the PRC. At least two knowledge products will be published on the ADB 
website by June 2020, with careful consideration given to the needs of the relevant target groups, 
including possible use of social media and digital approaches. 
 
11.  Output 3: Dialogue on effective localization of the Sustainable Development Goals 
enhanced. The TA will enhance dialogue, including among developing countries, by identifying 
and documenting good practices and by bringing together DMC representatives at the global and 
regional  levels  to  share  their  experiences  in  localizing  the  SDGs. The  GovTG  will  hold  a 
knowledge-sharing seminar in a DMC and an international seminar on Localizing Agenda 2030 
for Sustainable Development in Manila, preferably in close cooperation with the DeLoG,11 the 
Development Assistance Committee Network on Governance of the Organisation for Economic 
Co-operation and Development,12 and UNDP. The events will be based on a review of good 
practices from the region. The event documentation will be posted on k-learn, Development Asia, 
and the GovTG website. 
 
                                                
11 DeLoG is an informal network of 29 bilateral and multilateral development partners in the field of decentralization and 
local governance. It was established in 2006 and ADB joined in 2015. It functions as a network for knowledge 
exchanges among different organizations as well as a platform for joint learning. Development Partners Network on 
Decentralisation and Local Governance. www.delog.org/web. 
12 There is scope for cooperation on the work on social inclusion and SDG implementation included in the 2017–2018 
Network on Governance work plan.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
ADB Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6).13 The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency and will administer the TA. The GovTG Secretariat 
under the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will lead implementation. 
The GovTG Secretariat will support (i) workshop preparation, implementation, and evaluation; (ii) 
subproject identification, design, and implementation; and (iii) training and conferences.14 The TA 
will  be  implemented  in  close  coordination  with  the  ADB  Results  Management  and  Aid 
Effectiveness Division in the Strategy and Policy Department and through the ADB-wide SDG 
coordination  mechanism.  The  GovTG  Committee  will  serve  as  the  steering  group  for  TA 
implementation, monitoring, and reporting. The TA will be implemented from October 2017 to 
September 2020. All activities will be coordinated closely with regional departments and relevant 
DMC stakeholders and will be designed to add value to country, sector and thematic operational 
priorities in at least three regional departments. The TA will finance consulting services, reports 
and  other  knowledge  products,  and  workshops  and  conferences.  For  output  2,  a  call  for 
subproject proposals from operational departments for up to $225,000 will be issued on ADB 
Today once the TA is approved. Selection of subproject proposals will be conducted by the 
GovTG secretariat in close consultation with the GovTG Committee based on criteria such as 
operational  relevance,  linkages  to  country  partnership  strategies,  degree  of  institutional 
complexity, innovation, and learning potential. 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented in cooperation with partner organizations, such as the DeLoG, 
the  Development  Assistance  Committee  Network  on  Governance  of  the  Organisation  for 
Economic  Co-operation  and  Development,  the  Open  Government  Partnership,  UNDP,  and 
relevant country and regional institutions.  
 
15.  The TA will support cross-sector and -thematic work by coordinating closely with relevant 
sector and thematic groups, particularly through ongoing SDG-related TA projects.15 For instance, 
the Education Sector Group will be closely involved in the preparation of the education sector 
case study for the Multi-Stakeholder Engagement Program in the North Pacific, and the Urban 
Sector Group will be consulted on the PRC cities subproject under output 2. Cooperation with the 
Social Protection Thematic Group will examine issues with respect to social protection indicators 
and financing strategies for social protection; and cooperation with the Environment Thematic 
Group will emphasize pollution and loss of biodiversity. 
                                                
13 Cofinancing ($500,000) from the PRC Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund has been requested; if 
granted, this will be added through a change of scope, subject to management approval. The additional financing 
will be prioritized for expanding output 2 subproject coverage.         
14 Resource persons may include ADB staff with expertise in specialized areas to present in workshops. Travel costs 
and per diem for resource persons will be covered under the TA budget as indicated in Appendix 2.  
15 ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Strategies for Financing Social Protection to Achieve Sustainable Development 
Goals in Developing Member Countries. Manila; ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Supporting Implementation of 
Environment-Related Sustainable Development Goals in Asia and the Pacific. Manila.

5 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  October 2017–September 2020 
Executing agency  ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
(Governance Thematic Group) 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB  
ICS   17 person-months of international and 60  $683,000 
person-months of national consultants 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, ICS = individual consultants selection. 
Source: ADB. 
 
16.  Consulting services. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate all consultants. The TA is 
estimated to require 17 person-months of international consultant and 60 person-months of 
national consultant services, using individual consultants with expertise in governance, public 
sector management, decentralization and local governance, and/or capacity and institutional 
development. All consultants shall be engaged following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time), using output-based, lump-sum out-of-pocket contracts wherever possible.16 
The terms of reference for consultants will be further developed when specific TA activities are 
undertaken. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Institutions for Localizing the Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
  
 
                                                
16  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Appendix 1  7 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Awareness, knowledge, and skills for effective localization of SDGs in selected DMCs 
strengthened  
1.1 Assess existing awareness-raising programs prepared by other agencies such as UNDP (Q4 
2017–Q2 2018)  
1.2 Design course content for awareness-raising courses for different groups of stakeholders, including 
those involved in output 2 subprojects (Q4 2017–Q4 2019). 
1.3 Select and invite relevant participants for learning programs in close coordination with DMCs and 
operational departments (Q3 2018–Q4 2019). 
1.4 Customize multi-stakeholder engagement for reform learning program for North Pacific DMC 
participants from the education sector project (Q4 2017–Q1 2018). 
1.5 Conduct and evaluate learning programs in cooperation with partners (Q4 2017–Q4 2019). 
2.  Innovative institutional capacity interventions for localizing the SDGs in selected DMCs tested 
2.1 Identify, design, implement, and monitor targeted small-scale subprojects to address challenges 
with institutional capacity for localizing the SDGs in close cooperation with regional departments 
and relevant stakeholders (Q4 2017–Q1 2020). 
2.2 Provide specialized support for quality assurance, monitoring, and follow-on support (Q4 2017–Q1 
2020). 
2.3 Document subproject results, findings, and lessons (Q2 2020).  
3.  Dialogue on effective localization of the SDGs enhanced  
3.1 Identify good practices in institutional strengthening for localizing the SDGs, and draft case studies 
to inform conferences (Q4 2017–Q4 2019). 
3.2 Design, conduct, and document regional conference on localizing the SDGs in a DMC (Q4 2017–
Q4 2019).  
3.3 Design, conduct, and document an international conference on the Localizing Agenda 2030 for 
Sustainable Development in Manila (Q4 2017–Q4 2019). 
TA Management Activities 
Coordinate detailed activities with operational departments and DMCs.   
Recruit and manage international and national consultants in cooperation with operational departments and 
DMCs. 
Conduct inception and supervision missions for subprojects, where needed, and provide quality assurance 
of studies and learning programs and consultant reports. 
Organize and support the multi-stakeholder engagement learning program.  
Support and co-host a regional and an international conference. 
Administer the TA. 
Manage the project website and coordinate publications with the Department of External Relations.  
Disseminate knowledge products across DMCs and integrate these into knowledge and learning exercises.  
Submit the TA final report.  
Inputs 
ADB: $1,000,000b 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not Applicable  
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DMC = developing member country, PRC = People’s Republic of China, Q = quarter, 
SDG = Sustainable Development Goal, TA = technical assistance, UNDP = United Nations Development Programme. 
a  Defined by TA. 
b Cofinancing ($500,000) from the PRC Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund has been requested; if 
granted, this will be added through a change of scope, subject to management approval. The additional financing 
will be prioritized for expanding output 2 subproject coverage.           
Source: Asian Development Bank.
